data.title: Soviet pilots were inferior to the RAF pilots in WW II?
data.meta_description:
It is interesting also to see how many planes shot down one and the same German pilot, but on different fronts. 

Here is a German ace Walter Nowotny, the...
data.text:
It is interesting also to see how many planes shot down one and the same German pilot, but on different fronts.

Here is a German ace Walter Nowotny, the Luftwaffe was considered a favorite. Began fighting on the Eastern Front, and by February 1944 filled questionnaires of 255 were shot down Soviet aircraft. In February, moved to the Western Front, and even in the regiment's jet fighters. Over the last 8 months have not brought down any enemy planes! November 8 was shot down. The truth is that in this last fight he was "struck" 3 American bomber. But that "struck" blowing something "posthumous."

Hermann Graf in the Luftwaffe in 1938, but before the war with the Soviet Union but got no Polish or British aircraft. Transferred to the Eastern Front in August 1941 and then until the end of 1942 "knocks" Soviet aircraft in batches, filling out questionnaires to 202 pieces (17 months). From January 1943 - in France, and here until the end of the war for 29 months, he throws only 10 aircraft. Feel the difference between East and West: on the east knocked down more than 10 planes a month, and the West - 10 aircraft for 29 months!

Gunther Rall. Began fighting in May 1940 in France and knocked on the Western Front until the end of 1941 4 aircraft. Since the end of 1941 to April 1944 (for 28 months) knocks on the Eastern Front 275 aircraft. From April 1944 to May 1945 on the Western Front knocks only 2 aircraft.

The list could go.

Indeed Soviet pilots were inferior to British pilots?

Let the numbers talk.

These were the Top Ten figter aces for the R.A.F. (British & Commonwealth pilots) & the Soviet Air Forces for WW2, with their number of victories:

R.A.F. :

Marmaduke Pattle (South Africa) 51

James Johnson38 Brendan Finucane 32

Adolphus Malan (South Africa) 32

George Beurling (Canada) 31

William Vale 31

Clive Caldwell (Australia) 29

John Braham 29

Robert Tuck 29

James Lacey 28

Total: 330 victories.

Soviets:

Ivan Kozhedub 62

Alexandr Pokryshkin 59

Nikolay Gulaev 57

Grigoriy Rechkalov 56

Kirill Yevstigneev 53

Dmitriy Glinka 50

Arseniy Vorozheykin 46

Nikolay Skomorokhov 46

Alexandr Koldunov 46

Nikolay Krasnov 44

Total: 510 victories.

Of the British/Commonwealth aces, only Pattle would have ranked among the top ten Soviet aces (6th place).

BTW, the (partial) list of victories of Erich Hartmann (just the first 50; I was unable to post any more in this site)
